summary: Coretta Scott King was the wife of Martin Luther King Jr. The documents primarily mention her in the context of FBI investigations into Martin Luther King Jr., the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), and Stanley Levison. One document specifically mentions the CIA seeking information from the FBI regarding her intention to participate in the Australian Vietnam Moratorium Campaign in 1970. While the documents focus on investigations into her husband and his associates, her planned participation in the anti-war campaign highlights her own activism and international connections.
significance: Coretta King's significance in the JFK context, based on these documents, is indirect. She is mentioned in relation to investigations of her husband, Martin Luther King Jr., and his associates. The documents suggest surveillance and scrutiny of individuals connected to the civil rights movement during this period. Her planned participation in the Australian Vietnam Moratorium Campaign also highlights her involvement in anti-war activism.
